Problem:
Assume the function \( z(t) \) governed by the complex differential equation \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \) where \( \omega \) is a real number, represents a physical process. We explore the effects of the operation \( h(z) = e^{kt}z \) on \( z(t) \), with \( k \) being another real constant.

If another operation \( j(z) = e^{-kt}z \) is applied at a time \( t_1 \), will the resultant state \( z(T) \) for \( T > t_1 \) only depend on the properties of \( \omega \) and not on previous transformations with \( k \)?
Explanation: The additional operation \( j(z) \) influences the system depending on its timing and magnitude relative to \( k \). As both \( e^{kt} \) and \( e^{-kt} \) affect the scaling and rotation of the state, the final system state \( z(T) \) remains dependent on both parameters \( \omega \) and \( k \), influencing how the state was altered both before and after \( t_1 \).
